course_title: Sustainability in Tourism, Hospitality and Events

learning_outcomes.description: Explain key concepts related to sustainability in tourism, hospitality and events.
Identify different stakeholder perspectives in relation to sustainable tourism, hospitality and events issues.
Critically evaluate the impact of tourism, hospitality and events on a range of natural and built environments.
Discuss the socio-cultural impacts of tourism, hospitality and events, using examples from different cultures and different stages of development.
Provide strategies for the sustainable planning and management of tourism, hospitality and event activities.

assessments.task_description:
Students choose one of the 6 sites provided during tutorials in Week 2. Please note your chosen site will be applicable for all 3 assessment items as follows:

  • Assessment 1 – Site Impact Assessment (Identify impacts at your chosen site)
  • Assessment 2 – Stakeholder Meeting (Representing a stakeholder from your chosen site)
  • Assessment 3 – Sustainability Impact Management Plan (Prepare a plan of how you would manage the impacts at your chosen site)


Assessment 1:

As an expert in sustainability, you have been engaged by a tourism/ hospitality/ events (T/H/E) site manager to determine the status of the site in relation to sustainability. You will visit your chosen site to identify both positive and negative impacts.

Your task:

  • You will choose a site provided during your tutorial in Week 2.
  • Choose a site that you can visit at least once during the semester.
  • As the Assessments are linked, there can only be 5 students per tutorial group for each site.
  • Using the checklist provided on Blackboard, identify minimum 12 impacts - two (2) positive and two (2) negative impacts for each pillar (environmental, socio-cultural & economic).
  • Include photographs taken at the site to illustrate these impacts.


Word Limit: 1000 words


IMPORTANT: You can NOT approach employees, management or visitors to your site. This is a breach of UQ policy. This assessment is based on your analysis of your personal observations of the site. You will not be conducting surveys or interviewing people.

Format:

Template provided on Blackboard.

Use of AI/MT

The assessment tasks in this course have been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI/ MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your Site Impact Assessment must be submitted to Turnitin
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Stakeholder Meeting - During Class - Week 10 - Week 11

Reflection -1:00PM 18/05/2026

Your Stakeholder Meeting will be assessed during your tutorials in Week 10 and 11. Reflections are due Week 12 Monday 1pm.
assessments.task_description:
There are two (2) parts to Assessment 2 - Part A (Stakeholder Meeting) and Part B (Individual Reflection)

Part A - Stakeholder Meeting (30%)

Preparation in your tutorial:

  • You will be allocated to a group of five (5) based on your chosen site for Assessment 1
  • Each group will be allocated a scenario provided by your teacher
  • Each member in the group will be randomly allocated a stakeholder role that they will represent.
  • You will have 15 minutes to review your impacts identified in Assessment 1 from the perspective of your stakeholder.


Your Task:

  • During the tutorial your group will engage in a stakeholder meeting. You will be required to represent your stakeholder at this meeting.
  • The meeting will be facilitated by your teacher.
  • A detailed explanation of the purpose and process of a stakeholder meeting will be explained in class.


Format:

  • Role play
  • Handwritten dot points only to be used in the meeting.


Please Note: The presentation will be recorded for marking purposes per UQ Policy.

Use of AI/MT Technologies

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that can support this type of activity. Therefore, you are allowed to appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. 

 A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

 To pass this assessment, you will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension independent of AI and MT tools.


Part B - Individual Reflection (10%)

Reflect on your role play, and the other role plays from your tutorial.

  • Describe 3 impact compromises that were made during the meeting
  • What was your key learning from the meeting
  • Identify 3 learnings from the other stakeholder meetings (include the meeting details – site name and person, and what you learnt)
  • Written in 1st person

Format:

  • Word length - 500 words
  • Font size - 11 point
  • Font type - Calibri; Times New Roman; Arial
  • Line spacing - 1.5 spacing


Use of AI/MT

The assessment tasks in this course have been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI/ MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your Individual Reflection must be submitted to Turnitin via Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The manager of your site (from Assessment 1) has commissioned you to prepare a sustainability impact management report for the site. The purpose of this report is to improve the sustainability of the site.

Your task:

  • Provide strategies for selected impacts from Assessment 1 that optimise positive impacts and reduce / eliminate negative impacts. 
  • Clearly explain:  
  • What could be done 
  • Why this action is a good solution. 
  • Support your answer with lecture content, academic readings, industry examples (may be supported with photos from existing examples in action) 
  • How it will be monitored and measured 
  • Identify the potential impact your suggestions have on all pillars of the TBL with a brief discussion on each impact addressed. 


Document - Sustainability Impact Management Report.

Your Report must include:

  • Title page (assume the role of sustainability consultant and make this page professional and informative)
  • Executive Summary (one page overview of your whole report)
  • Table of Contents (use headings/ sub headings that are numbered and relevant to your site)
  • Introduction (Description of your site). Include a Table showing the Impacts identified in Assessment 1 highlighting those being addressed in your Report – 2 positive and 4 negative impacts 
  • Recommendations (Approximately 1500 words in total). Include elements as outlined above in ‘Your Task’ 
  • Conclusion (one paragraph to sum up)
  • Reference list (use APA7 referencing to reference all sources used in your report)
  • Appendices (include your photos / maps etc as appendices)


Format:

  • Word length: 2000 words (excluding Title Page: AI/MT Acknowledgement; Executive Summary; Table of Contents; Reference List; Appendices).
  • Referencing: APA7
  • Font size: 11 point
  • Font type: Calibri; Times New Roman; Arial
  • Line spacing: 1.5 spacing


Use of AI/MT:

The assessment tasks in this course have been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI/ MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction to key terms and concepts

This week we introduce the course and define sustainability and its relevance to THE. The triple bottom line will be explained and key sustainability challenges in THE introduced.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to key terms and concepts This week we introduce the course and define sustainability and its relevance to THE. The triple bottom line will be explained and key sustainability challenges in THE introduced.

learning_activities.topic:
No tutorials

No tutorials
learning_activities.topic_description: No tutorials No tutorials

learning_activities.topic:
Identifying and measuring impacts

This week we will start to identify environmental, social, and economic impacts and understand methods for measuring impacts.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Identifying and measuring impacts This week we will start to identify environmental, social, and economic impacts and understand methods for measuring impacts.

learning_activities.topic:
Meet, greet and assessment

Meet your tutor and classmates and unpack your assessment. You will also make a start on choosing your site that will be the basis of your assessment in this course.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Meet, greet and assessment Meet your tutor and classmates and unpack your assessment. You will also make a start on choosing your site that will be the basis of your assessment in this course.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainability challenges - Local & Global

This week we compare some of the local and global sustainability issues affecting THE. The Tourism Multiplier is also introduced along with its impact near and far.


Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Sustainability challenges - Local & Global This week we compare some of the local and global sustainability issues affecting THE. The Tourism Multiplier is also introduced along with its impact near and far.

learning_activities.topic:
Identifying impacts in practice

Activities in this tutorial will give you useful practice for your first assessment - Site Impact Assessment.


Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Identifying impacts in practice Activities in this tutorial will give you useful practice for your first assessment - Site Impact Assessment .

learning_activities.topic:
CSR, Sustainability Frameworks & Ethics

What exactly is Corporate Social Responsibility and what other sustainability frameworks exist? Who and what do they benefit and how ethical are they? Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are introduced.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: CSR, Sustainability Frameworks & Ethics What exactly is Corporate Social Responsibility and what other sustainability frameworks exist? Who and what do they benefit and how ethical are they? Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are introduced.

learning_activities.topic:
Global vs Local sustainability issues in THE

When do local sustainability actions in THE scale into meaningful global impacts? Which pillar has the most impact...environmental, socio-cultural or economic? Let's test this!


Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Global vs Local sustainability issues in THE
learning_activities.topic_description: Global vs Local sustainability issues in THE When do local sustainability actions in THE scale into meaningful global impacts? Which pillar has the most impact...environmental, socio-cultural or economic? Let's test this!

learning_activities.topic:
Environmental Management Systems

How do businesses manage their environmental impacts to keep their certification? This week we look at the different Environmental Management Systems across THE.


Learning outcomes: L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Environmental Management Systems How do businesses manage their environmental impacts to keep their certification? This week we look at the different Environmental Management Systems across THE.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainability strategies & ethical practices

First up, we look at an example of sustainable architecture right here on campus. Back in class we unpack sustainability strategies and ethical practices across THE by taking a close look at the UN Tourism Global Code of Ethics.


Sub-activity: Application of UN Tourism Global Code of Ethics

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Sustainability strategies & ethical practices First up, we look at an example of sustainable architecture right here on campus. Back in class we unpack sustainability strategies and ethical practices across THE by taking a close look at the UN Tourism Global Code of Ethics. learning_activities.topic:
Socio-cultural impacts

In this lecture we look at the socio-cultural impacts experienced by communities including Indigenous Australians.


Learning outcomes: L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Socio-cultural impacts In this lecture we look at the socio-cultural impacts experienced by communities including Indigenous Australians.

learning_activities.topic:
Identifying Impacts: South Bank excursion

Meet your tutor at South Bank where you will undertake a Site Audit. Instructions and a debrief will be provided by your tutor. This excursion provides you with a real world example of how to prepare for your first assessment (Site Impact Assessment).

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Identifying Impacts: South Bank excursion Meet your tutor at South Bank where you will undertake a Site Audit. Instructions and a debrief will be provided by your tutor. This excursion provides you with a real world example of how to prepare for your first assessment ( Site Impact Assessment ).

learning_activities.topic:
Carrying Capacity & Overtourism

This week we look at destination planning, carrying capacity and how overtourism represents a sustainability problem across environmental, socio-cultural and economic dimensions.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Carrying Capacity & Overtourism This week we look at destination planning, carrying capacity and how overtourism represents a sustainability problem across environmental, socio-cultural and economic dimensions.

learning_activities.topic:
Stakeholders in practice

Let's have some fun and play the board game Sustainable Island. This game will give you insights to your Stakeholder Meeting assessment in Weeks 10 & 11 and provide you with essential reflection techniques required for this assessment.

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Stakeholders in practice Let's have some fun and play the board game Sustainable Island . This game will give you insights to your Stakeholder Meeting assessment in Weeks 10 & 11 and provide you with essential reflection techniques required for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Tourist behaviour and greenwashing

An introduction to tourist behaviour and decision-making. We also identify some of the sneaky greenwashing tactics used in marketing THE and look at how this is monitored and enforced.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Tourist behaviour and greenwashing An introduction to tourist behaviour and decision-making. We also identify some of the sneaky greenwashing tactics used in marketing THE and look at how this is monitored and enforced.

learning_activities.topic:
Overtourism

How can overtourism threaten the sustainability of destinations? Which TH&E sectors contribute the most pressure — and which offer the best opportunities to reduce it?


Learning outcomes: L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Overtourism How can overtourism threaten the sustainability of destinations? Which TH&E sectors contribute the most pressure — and which offer the best opportunities to reduce it?

learning_activities.topic:
Events environmental and social impacts

Identify environmental and social impacts of events. What are sustainable event planning principles?


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Events environmental and social impacts Identify environmental and social impacts of events. What are sustainable event planning principles?

learning_activities.topic:
Greenwashing & Assessment prep

Where have you seen greenwashing in TH&E — hotels, airlines, festivals, tour operators? Let's find out what made you think it was greenwashing and what type it was. We also discuss some tips for the Stakeholder Meetings starting next week in tutorials.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Greenwashing & Assessment prep Where have you seen greenwashing in TH&E — hotels, airlines, festivals, tour operators? Let's find out what made you think it was greenwashing and what type it was. We also discuss some tips for the Stakeholder Meetings starting next week in tutorials.

learning_activities.topic:
Sustainable Sourcing

Identify impacts when sourcing products / resources - food, souvenirs, materials and staff! Is local really better? What about waste?

Learning outcomes: L03, L04

We identify smart and digital solutions that are being used to help THE providers to track and report on sustainability. We also look at how gamifying visitor / guest involvement contributes to sustainability.
